text.p: The following are top stories from selected Singapore newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong will visit Thailand from Monday through Wednesday to enhance bilateral relations.
- More child abuse cases being reported but referrals coming mainly from hospitals and police, Minister for Community Development Abdullah Tarmugi says.
- At least eight shop units in Boon Lay Shopping Complex destroyed by fire early on Sunday.
- Malaysia and Indonesia plan to build bridge across Malacca Straits to link peninsular Malaysia with Sumatra, Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad says.
- Arrival in Australia of 140 smartly dressed Asian boat people raisessuspicions of new racket in illegal immigrants, Australian government officials say.
- Royal Brothers put up for sale their Melia at Scotts hotel, and the freehold property, which can be redeveloped into condominiums, is expected to fetch about Singapore $200 million.
- Malaysian Finace Minister Anwar Ibrahim promises to take middle line on taxes in his October budget, as he is urged to provide incentives for small- and medium-sized businesses.

- Dialog Group Bhd subsidiary Dialog MCV Sdn Bhd signs letter of intent to carry out feasibility study on technical and economic viability of developing multi-billion ringgit fully integrated petroleum and petrochemical complex at Tanjung Pelepas, Johor.
- In surprising move, Malaysia's Securities Commision proposes to cut trade settlement period for Malaysia stock market to three trading days after transaction.
- Turning traditional assumptions on their heads, landed homes in outlying area of Woodlands now enjoy rentals rivalling those in prime districts.
- Britain's tax authorities putting pressure on metals dealers who profited from trades with Sumitomo copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka year ago.
- Mainboard listed seafood trader Pacific Andes Holdings has been on acquisition trail in foreign waters as part of aim to build global network.
